results.title: Building a bridge: Tajik
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
Shows how, in three days of actual construction, one hundred Tajik men and boys from one village work together to rebuild their hand-construction bridge. No narration.

results.title: Pierre et Paul = Pierre and Paul
results.creator_credit: Rene Allio, Yves Robert and Leon Carre
results.brief_description:
Pierre, a middle manager in a building company, decides to buy a appartment and live with his girlfriend, Martine. But, the subsequent death of his father and various financial difficulties soon damage his mental equilibrium. When the May ‘68 riots errupt, Pierre goes off the rails.

Credits: Producer, Leon Carre, Yves Robert ; director, Rene Allio ; writer, Rene Allio ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Jacques Dutronc.
Cast: Pierre Mondy, Robert Juillard, Bulle Ogier, Madeleine Barbulee, Helene Vincent.

results.title: Giron: bay of pigs
results.creator_credit: Instituto Cubano del Arte e Industrias Cinematográficos (ICAIC), Humberto Hernandez, Orlando de la Huertes and Manuel Herrera
results.brief_description: A dramatised documentary account of the failed CIA-sponsored assault at the Bay of Pigs in April, 1961. The operation subsequently created serious embarrassment for the U.S. government and led to wide-ranging political repercussions. Employing interviews with participants in the original events, re-enactments of the fighting and actual documentary footage of the assault, the film reconstructs the entire event, from the first air raid strikes to the retaking of Playa Giron by the revolutionary troops. Dramatised and documentary sequences are seamlessly blended to provide a dramatically compelling war narrative. Made with the participation of the Revolutionary Armed Forces.

results.title: Greta Thunberg detained at anti-mining protest
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @Nowthis Tiktok feed.
results.brief_description: Since 2018, activist Greta Thunberg has used social media to bring young people into the climate change conversation. Primarily active on Twitter and Instagram, she has organised and documented schools striking for climate action, protests, and sit-ins internationally – and recently sparred online with alt-right social media personality Andrew Tate, a high profile exchange that was interrupted by his arrest on rape and human trafficking charges. This video documenting her detainment at an anti-mining protest in Germany displays Thunberg’s characteristic staunchness, shot through with the impudence that makes her such a compelling campaigner.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Since 2018, activist Greta Thunberg has used social media to bring young people into the climate change conversation. Primarily active on Twitter and Instagram, she has organised and documented schools striking for climate action, protests and sit-ins internationally – and recently sparred online with alt-right influencer Andrew Tate, a high profile exchange that was interrupted by his arrest on human trafficking charges. This video of her detainment at an anti-mining protest in Germany displays Thunberg’s staunchness, shot through with the audacity that makes her such a compelling campaigner.
description_for_label: Since 2018, activist Greta Thunberg has used social media to bring young people into the climate change conversation. Primarily active on Twitter and Instagram, she has organised and documented schools striking for climate action, protests and sit-ins internationally – and recently sparred online with alt-right influencer Andrew Tate, a high profile exchange that was interrupted by his arrest on human trafficking charges. This video of her detainment at an anti-mining protest in Germany displays Thunberg’s staunchness, shot through with the audacity that makes her a compelling campaigner.

results.title: FAWN
results.brief_description:
FAWN connects characters from popular culture with everyday people who have the lived experience of losing a parent. Dressed in a kind of orphan drag and performing acts of care on each other, they form temporary bonds and act out unlikely intimacies. FAWN queers the notion of family and acknowledges that loss doesn’t always lead to a heroic coming of age adventure.

This work was commissioned by ACMI as part of a larger project commissioned by RISING.

results.title: Mother Courage
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, monitor, van, mixed media props, paintings, colour and sound
results.brief_description: Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

constellations_other.name: Warwick Thornton
constellations_other.description: Brimming with Shakespearean undertones and pathos, Kaytetye filmmaker Warwick Thornton's debut feature Samson and Delilah is both a universal tale and one intrinsically tied to the experience of First Peoples in Central Australia.

results.description:
Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play Mother Courage and Her Children the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

The installation comprises a white van housing a dual screen projection of an elderly Aboriginal woman artist and her grandson. Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.

Mother Courage is inspired by Bertolt Brecht’s famous character Mother Courage. In Brecht’s 1939 play, Mother Courage and Her Children, the title character, displaced by war, survives by moving and adapting to whatever life throws at her. In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.

Thornton’s Mother Courage was first exhibited in 2012 at the prestigious contemporary art exhibition dOCUMENTA (13) held in Kassel, Germany. For the period of the exhibition, it was constantly on the move, ‘parked outside the most prestigious galleries in town, for art aficionados to peer in its grimy windows through its rear doors, to wonder at the business inside’. At ACMI, the work was reborn within the space of Gallery 2, no longer on the move, but cutting against the grain of the white cube/black box experience of the art gallery space.
description_for_label:
Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

“The installation comprises a white van housing a dual screen projection of an elderly Aboriginal woman artist and her grandson. Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.
‘Mother Courage’ is inspired by Bertolt Brecht’s famous character Mother Courage. In Brecht’s 1939 play, ‘Mother Courage and her Children’, the title character, displaced by war, survives by moving and adapting to whatever life throws at her. In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.
Thornton’s ‘Mother Courage’ was first exhibited in 2012 at the prestigious contemporary art exhibition dOCUMENTA (13) held in Kassel, Germany. For the period of the exhibition, it was constantly on the move, ‘parked outside the most prestigious galleries in town, for art aficionados to peer in its grimy windows through its rear doors, to wonder at the business inside’. At ACMI, the work was reborn within the space of Gallery 2, no longer on the move, but cutting against the grain of the white cube/black box experience of the art gallery space.” [Source: ACMI Education resource kit]

results.title: Dr Phil's story
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Phil Bergman and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dr Phil Bergman is a pediatrician and endocrinologist. He was encouraged to become involved with the Victorian Turner’s Syndrome Association and has since become a specialist in the field. Over the years he has contributed greatly to the care of those with Turner’s Syndrome and values support for those with the condition as much as medical advancements in the area.
